column51:
When I use AI chatbots to translate a medicine leaflet, it gives an accurate translation, and since I am fluent in Arabic, English, and Chinese, I can assess the level of accuracy and quality of the translation.
As for the use in personal life, I use AI chatbots in my native language (Arabic) when I want to share something that's bothering me, and I get an excellent response as if a real person is consoling me.

column72: I believe there are many ways chatbots can benefit writers, but the developers aren’t doing enough to educate people on how to fully take advantage of these benefits. For instance, I had to take a course on O'Reilly to really understand how to use them effectively. I can’t overstate how many “Aha!” moments I had from the insights I gained, but the process wasn’t easy. I had to search deeply, and I also had some technical knowledge of chatbot development, which made it easier to grasp the course material. What I’m trying to say is that, despite some efforts, AI education hasn’t been made accessible enough to the general public.

column72: I think AI is a great tool that enhances writing, but I wouldn’t necessarily give AI the status of a writer. I believe that writing should stem from natural, realistic perception, which AI, for now, is too robotic to fully comprehend. An actual writer will not rely on AI to generate all their content, though the feedback given by AI can improve the quality of a written work. The key is to understand that the writer is fully in control of the direction the work is heading, as well as the final output, context, and tone. AI is like a car that can get you to a destination with ease, but you are in full control of the vehicle.

column40: My native language of Nkum. There are more than 500 unique languages spoken in Nigeria. Mine is just one of them, and we are the minority of the minorities. There aren't up to 20 thousand people who speak my language. I'm not sure whether my actual native language even has a written form. Since I left the village, I haven't spoken it once because I literaly haven't met anyone in the city who speaks it.

column72: I think AI has helped me accomplish more writing tasks than would have been possible without AI. I have had the chance to tackle complex subjects and delivered solid content because AI helped with creating the outline and guiding me through structuring content to fit requirements. If prompted well, AI is very good at fulfilling requests to the later. So if a writing task has a lot of requirements like number of points to discuss or length of content to produce, I reach for a chatbot to help me make sure all the requirements are met, then I can finetune the content to add some personality into it.

column51:
I teach at a trade high school that has many ELL whose native language is Spanish. I regularly use AI to help translate short instructions and allow them to turn their work in Spanish for specific assignments. AI helps me translate. I feel it is not 100% accurate, but it does provide enough accuracy to easily improve our communication as well as writing skills.

Overall, it is a useful tool, but it does require an understanding that it requires human use for accuracy. If it is being used as an end-all or without proofreading, it can easily confuse things.

column72: I truly believe that AI is here to stay and needs to be utilized in an ethical manner. It has some excellent qualities that can help with content creation, but freelance writing has all but dried up due to AI content creating that has removed the personalization of unique, written work. Businesses cannot compete with other companies that use AI materials for content creation since they can produce work at a much quicker rate. Unfortunetely, I have seen much of this work to be inaccurate as well. I have found it to be very helpful in my classroom to generate notes for students and to help take my own work and put it into presentations formats, thus saving me time. But so many students think it is always accurate and use it to avoid learning the skill of research and writing - thus lowering their overall abilities and narrowing their opportunities in the future. I would love to see disclosures surrounding AI use disclosures and required use courses being taught to help people be more aware of its pitfalls, and even its dangers to a younger audience (ie hyper sexualized chatbots).

column58: 𝗟𝗮𝗰𝗸 𝗼𝗳 𝗰𝘂𝗹𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲: AI isn’t able to generate content appropriate for specific audiences or cultures., 𝗘𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗿𝗻𝘀: One can’t be sure they own the work written with the help of an AI chatbot., I think using AI chatbots for professional writing can sometimes be unethical, in situations where a professional writer like me need to own the work. Mostly, the issue is putting the actual ideas in a human or natural perspective, where the AI will assist in brainstorming and idea generation, making the writer slightly rely on their own creativity. Further, mostly my writing is based on human health. In most cases, brainstorming ideas using AI chatbots provides general knowledge which might not apply effectively and ethically unless manually fine-tuned.

column51: I mainly use AI to translate text into different languages that I need for work. Sometimes I also receive text in a different language, and I need to translate it so I can understand what is being asked of me, then I just use the AI to translate back my response. I am not a native speaker at all of these languages and I tend to go back and forth between the AI chatbot, as well as Google Translate to check if the text makes sense. More often than not, the people who receive my reply back understand it and I think AI (specifically ChatGPT for this scenario) has improved drastically in terms of translating texts.

column72: I just wanted to share that AI is a good tool for when thinking of ideas or brainstorming, but writers like myself, should still write the final content and not be too heavily reliant on the text that AI produces. I sometimes cringe when I see social media posts, or even promotional ads wherein the copy sounds so fully-produced by AI. I think this practice should not be perpetuated as the quality of the ads and the writing that come out of it sound all about the same now.

column72: As much as AI has been very useful in helping me do my work, both in terms of the quality I can create and the speed with which I can create it, I know where AI is heading. I'm not just talking about AI taking my job from me, which it will, but the fact that it's end "goal", that is, the goal of those driving its development and adaption, is domination, control, manipulation, deception, brainwashing, and a bunch of other Orwellian nightmare things that I can see clearly barrelling towards us.

column72: Conclusively, in my opinion, I believe that for professional writers, AI chatbots are primarily tools to boost productivity, not a replacement for content creation or professional writing. What truly defines a professional writer is not the use of AI chatbots, but rather the years of knowledge, exposure, and experience they have gained in their field. If we rely entirely on AI chatbots for writing, then anyone, even a layperson, could potentially become a "professional" writer overnight through the misuse of the AI for content creation, without possessing the foundational knowledge required for professional writing. While I appreciate the use of AI chatbots for tasks like editing, fact-checking, and other supportive roles, I don't think they should replace the expertise and creativity that come from human writers. AI chatbots are definitely valuable, but they are best used as tools to complement the skills of a professional.

column72: The question of authorship is still a grey area. In many ways, GenAI models are like ghostwriters in that they follow guidelines (or are supposed to) set by the user. But the question, I feel, is about originality. Producing content by identifying patterns in preexisting data is not the same as creation. Then again, what is?
